def.name: unwrap
def.body:
atoms.coords.to_fract!
moved_atoms = Set(Atom).new
atoms.each_fragment do |fragment|
  assemble_fragment(fragment[0], fragment[0].coords, moved_atoms)
  fragment.coords.translate!(by: -fragment.coords.center.map(&.floor))
  moved_atoms.clear
end
atoms.coords.to_cart!

types.name: Quat
types.doc:
The quaternion is a mathematical construct that extends the complex
numbers and it is useful to encode three-dimensional rotations.
Quats are represented by four numbers (w, x, y, z), where w is
considered as the real (scalar) part and x, y, z the imaginary
(vector) part. Rotations can be encoded as a unit quaternion using
the axis-angle representation, where x, y, z correspond to the
rotation axis and w to the rotation angle by the following formula:

```text
q(v, t) = q(w, x, y, z) = q(cos(t/2), sin(t/2)vx, sin(t/2)vy, sin(t/2)vz)
```

where *v* is a unit vector and *t* is the rotation angle.
Quats have several useful mathematical properties, e.g.,
quaternion multiplication can be used to represent a sequence of
rotations producing a single quaternion. Indeed, the rotation
encoded in the quaternion *q* can be applied to a ordinary vector
*p* simply by

```text
p* = q * p * q-1
```

where *q*-1 is the inverse of *q* and *p** is the rotated vector
(see `Quat#*` for details).

## Examples

```
q = Quat[1, 2, 3, 4]
q                 # => [1.0 2.0 3.0 4.0]
q.real            # => 1.0
q.imag            # => [2.0 3.0 4.0]
q.w               # => 1.0
q.x               # => 2.0
q.y               # => 3.0
q.z               # => 4.0
-q                # => [-1.0 -2.0 -3.0 -4.0]
q.abs             # => 5.477225575051661
q.abs2            # => 30.0
q.conj            # => [1.0 -2.0 -3.0 -4.0]
q.inv             # => [0.033 -0.067 -0.1 -0.133]
q.normalize       # => [0.183 0.365 0.548 0.730]
q.unit?           # => false
q.normalize.unit? # => true
q.zero?           # => false

q * 2  # => [2.0 4.0 6.0 8.0]
q / 10 # => [0.2 0.4 0.6 0.8]

p = Quat[4, 3, 2, 1]
p + q # => [5.0 5.0 5.0 5.0]
p * q # => [-12.0 16.0 4.0 22.0]
q * p # => [-12.0 6.0 24.0 12.0]
```

Use the convenience methods to encode rotations.

```
v = Vec3[1, 2, 3]
q = Quat.aligning v, to: Vec3[1, 0, 0]
q * v # => [3.742 0.0 0.0]
# or
v.transform(q)    # => [3.742 0.0 0.0]
(q * v).normalize # => [1.0 0.0 0.0]

q = Quat.rotation Vec3[0, 1, 0], by: 90
q * v # => [3.0 2.0 -1.0]
v * q # => [-3.0 2.0 1.0]
```

NOTE: Quat multiplication is not commutative: `q * v != v *
p`, the former will apply the rotation encoded in *q* to *v* but the
latter will produce the inverse rotation. Use `Vec3#transform` to
avoid the ambiguity.
types.summary: The quaternion is a mathematical construct that extends the complex numbers and it is useful to encode three-dimensional rotations.

def.name: aligning
def.body:
w = u.cross(v)
Quat[(Math.sqrt(u.abs2 * v.abs2)) + (u.dot(v)), w.x, w.y, w.z].normalize

constructors.name: aligning
constructors.doc:
Returns a quaternion encoding the rotation to align *u[0]* to
*v[0]* and *u[1]* to *v[1]*.

First compute the alignment of *u[0]* to *v[0]*, then the
alignment of the transformed *u[1]* to *v[1]* on the plane
perpendicular to *v[0]* by taking their projections.
constructors.summary: Returns a quaternion encoding the rotation to align u[0] to v[0] and u[1] to v[1].
constructors.args_string: (u : Tuple(Vec3, Vec3), to v : Tuple(Vec3, Vec3)) : self

def.name: aligning
def.body:
q = Spatial::Quat.aligning(u[0], to: v[0])
qq = Spatial::Quat.aligning((q * u[1]).proj_plane(v[0]), to: v[1].proj_plane(v[0]))
qq * q

constructors.name: euler
constructors.doc:
Returns a quaternion encoding the rotation by the Euler angles.

The rotation rotates *x* degrees around the X axis, *y* degrees
around the Y axis, and *z* degrees around the y axis; applied in
that order (XYZ).
constructors.summary: Returns a quaternion encoding the rotation by the Euler angles.
constructors.args_string: (x : Number, y : Number, z : Number) : self
constructors.args_html: (x : Number, y : Number, z : Number) : self

def.name: euler
def.body:
cx = Math.cos(x.radians * 0.5)
sx = Math.sin(x.radians * 0.5)
cy = Math.cos(y.radians * 0.5)
sy = Math.sin(y.radians * 0.5)
cz = Math.cos(z.radians * 0.5)
sz = Math.sin(z.radians * 0.5)
Quat[((cx * cy) * cz) - ((sx * sy) * sz), ((sx * cy) * cz) + ((cx * sy) * sz), ((cx * sy) * cz) - ((sx * cy) * sz), ((cx * cy) * sz) + ((sx * sy) * cz)]

instance_methods.doc: Returns the Hamilton product of the quaternion and *rhs*.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the Hamilton product of the quaternion and rhs.

def.body:
w = (@w * rhs.w) - (imag.dot(rhs.imag))
v = ((@w * rhs.imag) + (rhs.w * imag)) + (imag.cross(rhs.imag))
Quat[w, v.x, v.y, v.z]

instance_methods.doc:
Returns the conjugate of *rhs* by the quaternion.

The conjugate of *rhs* is calculated as `p* = q * p * q^-1`, where
`p` is a quaternion whose vector part is *rhs* and real part
equals zero. Thus, the resulting quaternion is computed using the
Hamilton product and its vector part corresponds to `p*`. Such
operation can be written as `(self * rhs.to_q * inv).imag`, but
this method implements an optimized version by using some vector
and quaternion identities. The faster method is taken from this
[post](https://bit.ly/3G9FENX) of the molecular matters blog.

If the quaternion encodes a rotation about an axis, this
effectively applies such rotation to *rhs*.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the conjugate of rhs by the quaternion.

instance_methods.name: abs
instance_methods.doc: Returns the absolute value (norm or length) of the vector.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the absolute value (norm or length) of the vector.

instance_methods.name: abs2
instance_methods.doc: Returns the square of the absolute value of the vector.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the square of the absolute value of the vector.

instance_methods.name: close_to?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if the elements of the vectors are within *delta*
from each other, else `false`.

```
Vec3[1, 2, 3].close_to?(Vec3[1, 2, 3])                     # => true
Vec3[1, 2, 3].close_to?(Vec3[1.001, 1.999, 3.00004], 1e-3) # => true
Vec3[1, 2, 3].close_to?(Vec3[3, 2, 1])                     # => false
Vec3[1, 2, 3].close_to?(Vec3[1.001, 1.999, 3.00004], 1e-8) # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if the elements of the vectors are within delta from each other, else false.
instance_methods.args_html: (rhs : self, delta : Number = Float64::EPSILON) : Bool

instance_methods.name: cross
instance_methods.doc: Returns the cross product of the vector and *rhs*.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the cross product of the vector and rhs.

def.name: cross
def.body: Vec3[(@y * rhs.z) - (@z * rhs.y), (@z * rhs.x) - (@x * rhs.z), (@x * rhs.y) - (@y * rhs.x)]

instance_methods.name: dot
instance_methods.doc: Returns the dot product of the vector and *rhs*.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the dot product of the vector and rhs.

instance_methods.name: image
instance_methods.doc:
Returns vector's PBC image in fractional coordinates

```
vec = Vec3[0.456, 0.1, 0.8]
vec.image 1, 0, 0   # => Vec3[1.456, 0.1, 0.8]
vec.image -1, 0, 0  # => Vec3[-0.544, 0.1, 0.8]
vec.image -1, 1, -5 # => Vec3[-0.544, 1.1, -4.2]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns vector's PBC image in fractional coordinates
instance_methods.args_string: (i : Int, j : Int, k : Int) : self
instance_methods.args_html: (i : Int, j : Int, k : Int) : self

instance_methods.name: inv
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the inverse of the vector. It is equivalent to the unary
negation operator.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the inverse of the vector.

instance_methods.name: map
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a vector with the results of the component-wise mapping by
the given block. This is useful to perform non-standard
transformations.

```
Vec3[1, 2, 3].map(&.**(2)) # => Vec3[1.0, 4.0, 9.0]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a vector with the results of the component-wise mapping by the given block.

instance_methods.name: map_with_index
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a vector with the results of the component-wise mapping by
the given block yielding both the value and index. This is useful
to perform non-standard transformations.

```
Vec3[1, 2, 3].map { |ele, i| ele * i } # => Vec3[0.0, 2.0, 6.0]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a vector with the results of the component-wise mapping by the given block yielding both the value and index.

instance_methods.name: normalize
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the unit vector pointing in the same direction of the
vector.

```
v = Vec3[2.5, 0, 0].normalize # => Vec[1.0, 0.0, 0.0]
v.abs                         # => 1.0
v = Vec3[1, 1, 1].normalize   # => Vec[0.577, 0.577, 0.577]
v.abs                         # => 1.0
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the unit vector pointing in the same direction of the vector.

instance_methods.name: pad
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a vector by increasing the length by *padding*.

```
Vec3[1, 0, 0].pad(2) # => Vec3[3, 0, 0]
a = Vec3[1, 2, 3]
a.abs                             # => 3.7416573867739413
b = a.pad(2)                      # => Vec3[1.535, 3.069, 4.604]
b.abs                             # => 5.741657386773941
a.normalize.close_to? b.normalize # => true
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a vector by increasing the length by padding.

instance_methods.name: proj
instance_methods.doc: Returns the projection of the vector on *vec*.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the projection of the vector on vec.

instance_methods.name: proj_plane
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the projection of the vector on the plane perpendicular
to *normal*.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the projection of the vector on the plane perpendicular to normal.

instance_methods.name: resize
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a vector pointing in the same direction with the given
length.

```
a = Vec3[1, 2, 3]
a.abs                              # => 3.7416573867739413
b = a.resize 0.5                   # => Vec3[0.134, 0.267, 0.401]
b.abs                              # => 0.5
b.normalize.close_to?(a.normalize) # => true
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a vector pointing in the same direction with the given length.

def.name: resize
def.body:
if zero?
  return dup
end
self * (length / abs)

def.name: wrap
def.body:
offset = self - (center - Vec3[0.5, 0.5, 0.5])
self - offset.map do |ele|
  ele == 1 ? 0 : ele.floor
end

constructors.name: read
constructors.doc:
Returns the structure encoded in the specified file
using *format*. Raises `ArgumentError` if *format* has
required arguments or cannot read `Chem::Structure`.

If *input* contains multiple entries, this method returns
the first one only. Use `Array.read` or
`Chem::FormatReader::MultiEntry#each` (reader can be
obtained via `Chem::Format.reader`) to get multiple entries
instead.

The supported file formats are `Chem::Cube`, `Chem::Gen`, `Chem::Mol2`, `Chem::PDB`, `Chem::VASP::Chgcar`, `Chem::VASP::Locpot`, `Chem::VASP::Poscar`, `Chem::XYZ`. Use the
`.from_*` methods to customize how the object is decoded in
the corresponding file format if possible.
constructors.summary: Returns the structure encoded in the specified file using format.
constructors.args_string: (input : IO | Path | String, format : Chem::Format | String) : self
constructors.args_html: (input : IO | Path | String, format : Chem::Format | String) : self

def.name: read
def.body:
if format.is_a?(String)
  format = ::Chem::Format.parse(format)
end
case format
when .gen?
  from_gen(input)
when .mol2?
  from_mol2(input)
when .pdb?
  from_pdb(input)
when .xyz?
  from_xyz(input)
when .poscar?
  from_poscar(input)
when .cube?
  from_cube(input)
when .chgcar?
  from_chgcar(input)
when .locpot?
  from_locpot(input)
else
  raise(ArgumentError.new("#{format} does not encode Chem::Structure"))
end

constructors.name: read
constructors.doc:
Returns the structure encoded in the specified file.
The file format is chosen based on the filename (see
`Chem::Format#from_filename`). Raises `ArgumentError` if the
file format cannot be determined.

If the file contains multiple entries, this method returns
the first one only. Use `Array.read` to get multiple entries
instead.

The supported file formats are the following:

- `Chem::Gen` (.gen)
- `Chem::Mol2` (.mol2)
- `Chem::PDB` (.ent, .pdb)
- `Chem::XYZ` (.xyz)
- `Chem::VASP::Poscar` (.poscar, POSCAR, CONTCAR)
- `Chem::Cube` (.cube)
- `Chem::VASP::Chgcar` (CHGCAR)
- `Chem::VASP::Locpot` (LOCPOT)

Use the `.from_*` methods to customize how the object is
decoded in the corresponding file format if possible.
constructors.summary: Returns the structure encoded in the specified file.

instance_methods.name: clone
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a deep copy of `self`, that is, every chain/residue/atom is copied.

Unlike array-like classes in the language, `#dup` (shallow copy) is not possible.

```
structure = Structure.new "/path/to/file.pdb"
other = structure.clone
other == structure     # => true
other.same?(structure) # => false

structure.dig('A', 23, "OG").partial_charge         # => 0.0
other.dig('A', 23, "OG").partial_charge             # => 0.0
structure.dig('A', 23, "OG").partial_charge = 0.635 # => 0.635
other.dig('A', 23, "OG").partial_charge             # => 0.0
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a deep copy of self, that is, every chain/residue/atom is copied.

def.name: clone
def.body:
structure = Structure.new(@source_file)
structure.biases.concat(@biases)
structure.experiment = @experiment
structure.cell = @cell
structure.title = @title
each_chain(&.copy_to(structure))
bonds.each do |bond|
  a, b = bond
  a = structure.dig(a.chain.id, a.residue.number, a.residue.insertion_code, a.name)
  b = structure.dig(b.chain.id, b.residue.number, b.residue.insertion_code, b.name)
  a.bonds.add(b, order: bond.order)
end
structure

def.name: each_atom
def.body:
iterators = [] of Iterator(Atom)
each_chain do |chain|
  chain.each_residue do |residue|
    iterators << residue.each_atom
  end
end
Iterator.chain(iterators)

def.name: each_atom
def.body:
@chains.each do |chain|
  chain.each_atom do |atom|
    yield atom
  end
end

def.name: each_residue
def.body:
@chains.each do |chain|
  chain.each_residue do |residue|
    yield residue
  end
end

Appends a String representation of this object
which includes its class name, its object address
and the values of all instance variables.

```
class Person
  def initialize(@name : String, @age : Int32)
  end
end

Person.new("John", 32).inspect # => #<Person:0x10fd31f20 @name="John", @age=32>
```
instance_methods.summary: Appends a String representation of this object which includes its class name, its object address and the values of all instance variables.

instance_methods.name: renumber_residues_by
instance_methods.doc:
Renumber residues per chain based on the order by the output value
of the block.

NOTE: This won't change the order of the existing chains.
instance_methods.summary: Renumber residues per chain based on the order by the output value of the block.

def.name: renumber_residues_by
def.body:
each_chain do |chain|
  chain.renumber_residues_by do |residue|
    yield residue
  end
end

instance_methods.name: renumber_residues_by_connectivity
instance_methods.doc:
Renumber chain and residues based on bond information.

Residue fragments are assigned to unique chains unless
*split_chains* is `false`, which keeps existing chains intact.
Residue ordering is computed based on the link bond if available.

NOTE: existing chains are reused to re-arrang the residues among
them, so avoid caching them before calling this.
instance_methods.summary: Renumber chain and residues based on bond information.

def.name: renumber_residues_by_connectivity
def.body:
if split_chains
  id = 'A'.pred
  residues.residue_fragments.each do |residues|
    chain = (dig?(id = id.succ)) || (Chain.new(id, self))
    chain.clear
    residues.each(&.chain = chain)
    chain.renumber_residues_by_connectivity
  end
else
  each_chain(&.renumber_residues_by_connectivity)
end

instance_methods.doc:
Appends a short String representation of this object
which includes its class name and its object address.

```
class Person
  def initialize(@name : String, @age : Int32)
  end
end

Person.new("John", 32).to_s # => #<Person:0x10a199f20>
```

def.name: to_s
def.body:
io << "<Structure"
if title.blank?
else
  (io << " ") << title.inspect
end
io << ": "
(io << n_atoms) << " atoms"
if n_residues > 1
  ((io << ", ") << n_residues) << " residues"
end
io << ", "
if @cell
else
  io << "non-"
end
io << "periodic>"

instance_methods.name: write
instance_methods.doc:
Writes the structure to *output* using *format*. Raises
`ArgumentError` if *format* has required arguments or cannot
write `Chem::Structure`.

The supported file formats are `Chem::Gen`, `Chem::Mol2`, `Chem::PDB`, `Chem::Protein::Stride`, `Chem::PyMOL`, `Chem::VASP::Poscar`, `Chem::VMD`, `Chem::XYZ`. Use the
`#to_*` methods to customize how the object is written in the
corresponding file format if possible.
instance_methods.summary: Writes the structure to output using format.
instance_methods.args_string: (output : IO | Path | String, format : Chem::Format | String) : Nil
instance_methods.args_html: (output : IO | Path | String, format : Chem::Format | String) : Nil

def.name: write
def.body:
if format.is_a?(String)
  format = ::Chem::Format.parse(format)
end
case format
when .gen?
  to_gen(output)
when .mol2?
  to_mol2(output)
when .pdb?
  to_pdb(output)
when .pymol?
  to_pymol(output)
when .vmd?
  to_vmd(output)
when .xyz?
  to_xyz(output)
when .stride?
  to_stride(output)
when .poscar?
  to_poscar(output)
else
  raise(ArgumentError.new("#{format} does not encode Chem::Structure"))
end

instance_methods.name: write
instance_methods.doc:
Writes the structure to the specified file. The file
format is chosen based on the filename (see
`Chem::Format#from_filename`). Raises `ArgumentError` if the
file format cannot be determined.

The supported file formats are the following:

- `Chem::Gen` (.gen)
- `Chem::Mol2` (.mol2)
- `Chem::PDB` (.ent, .pdb)
- `Chem::PyMOL` (.pml)
- `Chem::VMD` (.vmd)
- `Chem::XYZ` (.xyz)
- `Chem::Protein::Stride` (.stride)
- `Chem::VASP::Poscar` (.poscar, POSCAR, CONTCAR)

Use the `#to_*` methods to customize how the object is written
in the corresponding file format if possible.
instance_methods.summary: Writes the structure to the specified file.

def.name: bond
def.body:
bond = atoms[i].bonds.add(atoms[j], order)
if aromatic
  aromatic_bonds << bond
end
bond

def.name: bonds
def.body:
atom_table = {} of Int32 => Atom
atom_serials = Set(Int32).new(bond_table.size * 2)
bond_table.each_key do |__arg3|
  i = __arg3[0]
  j = __arg3[1]
  (atom_serials << i) << j
end
@structure.each_atom do |atom|
  if atom.serial.in?(atom_serials)
    atom_table[atom.serial] = atom
  end
end
bond_table.each do |__arg4, order|
  i = __arg4[0]
  j = __arg4[1]
  if (lhs = atom_table[i]?) && (rhs = atom_table[j]?)
    lhs.bonds.add(rhs, order)
  end
end

instance_methods.name: guess_residues
instance_methods.doc:
Guesses residues from existing bonds.

Atoms are split in fragments, where each fragment is mapped to a list of residues.
Then, fragments are divided into polymers (e.g., peptide) and non-polymer
fragments (e.g., water), where residues assigned to the latter are grouped
together by their kind (i.e., protein, ion, solvent, etc.). Finally, polymer
fragments and residues grouped by kind are assigned to their own unique chain as
long as there are less residue groups than the chain limit (62), otherwise all
residues are assigned to the same chain.
instance_methods.summary: Guesses residues from existing bonds.

def.name: guess_residues
def.body:
matches_per_fragment = detect_residues(@structure.atoms)
builder = Structure::Builder.new(@structure.clear)
matches_per_fragment.each do |matches|
  builder.chain do
    matches.each do |m|
      residue = builder.residue(m.resname)
      residue.kind = m.reskind
      m.each_atom do |atom, atom_name|
        atom.name = atom_name
        atom.residue = residue
      end
    end
  end
end
@structure.renumber_residues_by_connectivity(split_chains: false)
assign_residue_types

def.name: guess_topology
def.body:
if @structure.n_atoms > 0
else
  return
end
apply_templates
build_connectivity(@structure.atoms)
if !@structure.residues.any? do |res|
  res.protein? && (!res.has_hydrogens?)
end
  assign_bond_orders(@structure.atoms)
  assign_formal_charges(@structure.atoms)
end
assign_residue_types

def.name: build
def.body:
builder = Templates::Builder.new(kind)
with builder yield builder
builder.build

def.name: aminoacid
def.body:
ResidueType.build(Residue::Kind::Protein) do |builder|
  with builder yield builder
  residue = builder.build
  builder.names.each do |name|
    if TEMPLATES.has_key?(name)
      raise(Error.new("Duplicate residue template #{name}"))
    end
    TEMPLATES[name] = residue
  end
end

  with builder yield builder
  residue = builder.build
  builder.names.each do |name|
    if TEMPLATES.has_key?(name)
      raise(Error.new("Duplicate residue template #{name}"))
    end
    TEMPLATES[name] = residue
  end
end

  builder.names.each do |name|

end

types.name: Colorize
types.doc:
With `Colorize` you can change the fore- and background colors and text decorations when rendering text
on terminals supporting ANSI escape codes. It adds the `colorize` method to `Object` and thus all classes
as its main interface, which calls `to_s` and surrounds it with the necessary escape codes
when it comes to obtaining a string representation of the object.

Its first argument changes the foreground color:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize(:green)
100.colorize(:red)
[1, 2, 3].colorize(:blue)
```

There are alternative ways to change the foreground color:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize.fore(:green)
"foo".colorize.green
```

To change the background color, the following methods are available:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize.back(:green)
"foo".colorize.on(:green)
"foo".colorize.on_green
```

You can also pass an RGB color to `colorize`:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize(0, 255, 255) # => "foo" in aqua

# This is the same as:

"foo".colorize(Colorize::ColorRGB.new(0, 255, 255)) # => "foo" in aqua
```

Or an 8-bit color:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize(Colorize::Color256.new(208)) # => "foo" in orange
```

It's also possible to change the text decoration:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize.mode(:underline)
"foo".colorize.underline
```

The `colorize` method returns a `Colorize::Object` instance,
which allows chaining methods together:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize.fore(:yellow).back(:blue).mode(:underline)
```

With the `toggle` method you can temporarily disable adding the escape codes.
Settings of the instance are preserved however and can be turned back on later:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize(:red).toggle(false)              # => "foo" without color
"foo".colorize(:red).toggle(false).toggle(true) # => "foo" in red
```

The color `:default` leaves the object's representation as it is but the object is a `Colorize::Object` then
which is handy in conditions such as:

```
require "colorize"

"foo".colorize(Random::DEFAULT.next_bool ? :green : :default)
```

Available colors are:
```
:default
:black
:red
:green
:yellow
:blue
:magenta
:cyan
:light_gray
:dark_gray
:light_red
:light_green
:light_yellow
:light_blue
:light_magenta
:light_cyan
:white
```

Available text decorations are:
```
:bold
:bright
:dim
:underline
:blink
:reverse
:hidden
```
types.summary: With Colorize you can change the fore- and background colors and text decorations when rendering text on terminals supporting ANSI escape codes.

types.name: ColorRGB
types.doc: An RGB color.
types.summary: An RGB color.

types.name: Float
types.doc:
Float is the base type of all floating point numbers.

There are two floating point types, `Float32` and `Float64`,
which correspond to the [binary32](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_precision_floating-point_format)
and [binary64](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_precision_floating-point_format)
types defined by IEEE.

A floating point literal is an optional `+` or `-` sign, followed by
a sequence of numbers or underscores, followed by a dot,
followed by numbers or underscores, followed by an optional exponent suffix,
followed by an optional type suffix. If no suffix is present, the literal's type is `Float64`.

```
1.0     # Float64
1.0_f32 # Float32
1_f32   # Float32

1e10   # Float64
1.5e10 # Float64
1.5e-7 # Float64

+1.3 # Float64
-0.5 # Float64
```

The underscore `_` before the suffix is optional.

Underscores can be used to make some numbers more readable:

```
1_000_000.111_111 # better than 1000000.111111
```

See [`Float` literals](https://crystal-lang.org/reference/syntax_and_semantics/literals/floats.html) in the language reference.
types.summary: Float is the base type of all floating point numbers.

instance_methods.name: close_to?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if numbers are within *delta* from each other, else `false`.

```
1.0.close_to?(1.0)                          # => true
1.0_f32.close_to?(1.0)                      # => true
1.0.close_to?(1.0 + Float64::EPSILON)       # => true
1.0_f32.close_to?(1.0 + Float32::EPSILON)   # => true
1.0.close_to?(1.0005, 1e-3)                 # => true
1.0.close_to?(1.0 + Float64::EPSILON*2)     # => false
1.0_f32.close_to?(1.0 + Float32::EPSILON*2) # => false
1.0.close_to?(1.01, 1e-3)                   # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if numbers are within delta from each other, else false.

types.name: Indexable
types.doc:
A container that allows accessing elements via a numeric index.

Indexing starts at `0`. A negative index is assumed to be
relative to the end of the container: `-1` indicates the last element,
`-2` is the next to last element, and so on.

Types including this module are typically `Array`-like types.
types.summary: A container that allows accessing elements via a numeric index.

def.name: mean
def.body:
{% unless @type.type_vars[0] < Number
  raise("#mean only works with numbers, not #{@type}")
end %}
(sum(0)) / size

def.name: mean
def.body:
sum do |ele|
  yield ele
end / size

instance_methods.name: scale
instance_methods.doc:
Scales the number into the given range. The result will be between
zero and one.

```
10.scale(0, 100)   # => 0.1
2.5.scale(0, 5)    # 0.5
401.scale(50, 500) # => 0.78
```

types.name: Range
types.doc:
A `Range` represents an interval: a set of values with a beginning and an end.

Ranges may be constructed using the usual `new` method or with literals:

```
x..y  # an inclusive range, in mathematics: [x, y]
x...y # an exclusive range, in mathematics: [x, y)
(x..) # an endless range, in mathematics: >= x
..y   # a beginless inclusive range, in mathematics: <= y
...y  # a beginless exclusive range, in mathematics: < y
```

See [`Range` literals](https://crystal-lang.org/reference/syntax_and_semantics/literals/range.html) in the language reference.

An easy way to remember which one is inclusive and which one is exclusive it
to think of the extra dot as if it pushes *y* further away, thus leaving it outside of the range.

Ranges typically involve integers, but can be created using arbitrary objects
as long as they define `succ` (or `pred` for `reverse_each`), to get the
next element in the range, and `<` and `==`, to know when the range reached the end:

```
# Represents a string of 'x's.
struct Xs
  include Comparable(Xs)

  getter size

  def initialize(@size : Int32)
  end

  def succ
    Xs.new(@size + 1)
  end

  def <=>(other)
    @size <=> other.size
  end

  def inspect(io)
    @size.times { io << 'x' }
  end

  def to_s(io)
    io << @size << ' '
    inspect(io)
  end
end
```

An example of using `Xs` to construct a range:

```
r = Xs.new(3)..Xs.new(6)
r.to_s                 # => "xxx..xxxxxx"
r.to_a                 # => [Xs.new(3), Xs.new(4), Xs.new(5), Xs.new(6)]
r.includes?(Xs.new(5)) # => true
```
types.summary: A Range represents an interval: a set of values with a beginning and an end.

def.name: clamp
def.body:
if exclusive?
  raise(ArgumentError.new("Can't clamp an exclusive range"))
end
if (b = @begin) && (e = @end)
  (b.clamp(min, max))..(e.clamp(min, max))
else
  if b = @begin
    (b.clamp(min, max))..max
  else
    if e = @end
      min..(e.clamp(min, max))
    else
      min..max
    end
  end
end

def.name: clamp
def.body:
if range.end.nil? || (!range.exclusive?)
  clamp(range.begin, range.end)
else
  raise(ArgumentError.new("Can't clamp by an exclusive range"))
end
